Two McKinsey experts share their insights.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fretail%2Four%20insights%2Fretail%20supply%20chain%20strategies%20for%20the%20holidays%20and%20beyond%2Fretail-supply-chain-strategies-for-the-holidays-and-beyond_final.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="retail-supply-chain-strategies-for-the-holidays-and-beyond_final" data-layer-report-name="retail-supply-chain-strategies-for-the-holidays-and-beyond_final>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (7 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>The disruptions in the global </strong>supply chain are the result of a confluence of factorswhich means that retailers have to take action on multiple fronts if they want their store shelves stocked and online orders fulfilled on time. In this episode of the <em>McKinsey on Consumer and Retail</em> podcast, retail supply-chain experts John Barbee and Sarah Touse offer advice to retailers ahead of whats shaping up to be another unusual holiday season. <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast">Subscribe to the podcast</a>.</p>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Monica Toriello: </strong>If you havent done your holiday shopping yet, it might already be too late. That seems to be one of the takeaways from all the recent headlines about disruptions in the global supply chain. As has been reported, there are many reasons for these disruptions, so there isnt one magic solution for retailers. Today, our two guests will share their insights on the range of supply-chain issues and what retailers can do in advance of whats sure to be a challenging holiday shopping season.</p>
<p>John Barbee is a partner based in McKinseys Atlanta office. He works with many retailers and consumer-goods companies on their omnichannel, supply-chain, and fulfillment strategies. He is one of the authors of a recent article titled <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/retails-need-for-speed-unlocking-value-in-omnichannel-delivery">Retails need for speed: Unlocking value in omnichannel delivery</a>.</p>
<p>Sarah Touse is an associate partner in McKinseys Boston office. Sarah, like John, has advised a wide range of retailers and consumer-goods players on supply-chain topics. Sarah has coauthored a number of retail articles, including one most recently on how retailers can build supply-chain resilience. Thanks for joining us, John and Sarah.</p>
<p>Theres been a lot of press about the <a href="/featured-insights/themes/stretched-global-supply-chains-and-shortages">supply-chain crisis</a>, and its been attributed to a host of factors: logjams at ports; huge, unanticipated spikes in consumer demand; labor shortages; and so on. From your perspective, is there one thing thats the biggest problem? Or are they all equally big problems?</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee: </strong>Thats a conundrum, Monica. Theres no single biggest problem. The good news is that some of the disruptions will pass, such as overseas vessel delays and container shortages. For these issues, the optimist would venture that theyd be resolved by the first half or early second half of next year. However, the pessimist might see this backlog last through 2023.</p>
<p>The other issuessuch as labor shortageshave been a long time in the making. Hourly wage rates have escalated over 20 percent in the past 18 months, and <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/how-tech-will-revolutionize-retail">investments in technology</a> and <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/automation-in-retail-an-executive-overview-for-getting-ready">automation</a> in distribution centers have been elevated and are now <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/how-retail-can-adapt-supply-chains-to-win-in-the-next-normal">at the forefront of most chief supply-chain officers agendas</a>.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Investments in technology and automation in distribution centers are now at the forefront of most chief supply-chain officers agendas.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">John Barbee</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse: </strong>The numbers are just staggering. If you look at the resignation rate, its 13 percent higher than prepandemic levels. During the pandemic, 3.5 million people retired, which is two million more than usual. There are ten million job openings right now. Theres a whole host of factors underneath that, but for me one of the takeaways is just how fundamentally this pandemic has changed how Americansand people around the world<a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours">think about their careers and their jobs</a> and how they want to spend time.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Subscribe to the <em>McKinsey on Consumer and Retail</em> podcast</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail/id1526250428" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c" target="_blank"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Apple Podcasts</span></a><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="https://open.spotify.com/show/41D4bro8PPDOGhEgOEJyHB?si=7l3SeYCZQD-7v3toqd9fHQ" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c" target="_blank"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Spotify</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Retailer strategies and no-regrets moves</h2>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Monica Toriello:</strong> What are some things that retailers have done that really made a difference in their supply chain or gave them competitive advantage?</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse: </strong>There are a few things that smart retailers have done. One is around pricing and promotions timing. Whereas in some years Black Friday would be the day when the holiday season starts, this year we saw <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/us-holiday-shopping-2021-strong-demand-meets-big-challenges">holiday pricing and promotions</a> as early as October. Some of that pull forward to smooth out the demand curve has been important.</p>
<p>Another thing that retailers have done is to thoughtfully raise prices. Some of the increases in logistics costs cant be avoided even if you are a smart retailer, so understanding how much of that you can take to your bottom line and how much of it has to be passed along to the consumerand then thinking about how to do it in a way thats minimally disruptive to the consumerhas been really important.</p>
<p>And then, finally, retailers are thinking about supply-chain triage. Many retailers, earlier in the fall, recognized that these challenges were deep and they anticipated that theyd have trouble getting product when they wanted it. So, retailers that have been mindful about which products are most important to get onto shelvestaking into account <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/can-your-supply-chain-deliver-what-your-consumer-wants">what consumers want</a>, as well as their own revenues and marginsare seeing that advantage play out as we get closer to the holidays.</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee:</strong> There have been a few interesting retailer strategies that arent necessarily available to all retailers, but weve certainly read about some retailerssuch as Home Depot, Costco, Walmart, Ikea, Target, and otherstaking some of the shipping issues into their own hands, so it gives them a little bit more control. Theyve done this by leasing vessels to carry their containers from overseas.</p>
<p>Other retailers pre-bought capacity, particularly air freight. For those retailers that have more speed-sensitive product or seasonal product, this proved to be a good strategy in that they were able to bypass some of the shipping disruption. And in cases where they had excess capacity, they could even sell it to others.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> For last-mile delivery, historically, many retailers thought, Ive got FedEx, UPS, and the US Postal Service. Those retailers are seeing the pain right now of very congested large integrator networks. A retailer that is now facing a little bit less pain is one that, a few years ago, decided to lean much more heavily on regional playersthe LaserShips of the worldand that has enabled the retailer to have more avenues to get their products directly to consumers.</p>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello:</strong> Are there any no-regrets moves that retailers should be making right now?</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee: </strong>It comes down to the basics of <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/into-the-fast-lane-how-to-master-the-omnichannel-supply-chain">omnichannel fulfillment operations</a>. I think of this in two parts.</p>
<p>Part one is that retailers should seek to maximize availability of product across all channels, offer convenient options for fulfilling demand, and make sure that the value of their product and fulfillment conveniences remains competitive in their market. In our latest consumer research, we find that <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/understanding-and-shaping-consumer-behavior-in-the-next-normal">consumers continue to change their shopping behavior</a>, with three-quarters making some change and 40 percent completely changing brands because of the lack of availability or perceived value in fulfillment. For chief supply-chain officers, this will mean working closely with their digital and store counterparts this holiday season to ensure that they have the blocking and tackling in place to deliver fast and reliable fulfillment to consumers.</p>
<p>Part two is innovate. During this pandemic, retailers have really pushed the envelope on innovation. Things like curbside pickup, buy online and pick up in store, and even concierge servicesthese things came to life faster than most retailers would have anticipated and fundamentally changed the way retailers think about deploying and testing new capabilities. So I think we will start to see a lot of experimentation with fulfillment models.</p>
<p>We may see more partnerships. For instance, Best Buy partnered with Instacart, which has traditionally served the grocery market. The same is happening in the beauty category with Sephora. Kohls for some time has been taking Amazon returns. So theres been a lot of <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/the-path-forward-for-the-us-retail-industry">innovation in retail</a>, and I think well continue to see more.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse: </strong>Ill highlight two things. The first is around visibility: the ROI of investing in greater data assets is always tricky for retailers. This pandemic has made it clear that data are important. Our recent research shows that a typical company will lose more than 40 percent of one years EBITDA [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization] over the next ten years because of disruption. Those numbers make the investment in datato enable retailers to have a more dynamic supply chainreally seem well worth it.</p>
<p>Second, retailers can do a lot to shape customer demand. As retailers think about how to push customers to buy online and pick up in store so that they can avoid some of that congested small-parcel market, and as they think about how to change shipping speeds and promises for different customer segments, its important to remember that customers react differently. There are things that retailers can do to shape some of those expectations.</p>
<h2>The need for visibility</h2>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello: </strong>Both of you have mentioned visibility. Sarah, in your recent article, one of the things you say retailers must do in the near term is stand up a digital control tower so that they can have <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/building-a-digital-bridge-across-the-supply-chain-with-nerve-centers">real-time visibility into whats happening in the supply chain</a> rather than having their data reside in siloed systems. You say a digital control tower typically improves fill rate by 10 percent and reduces excess inventory by more than 30 percent.</p>
<p>Can you give us a sense of how hard it is for retailers to establish a digital control tower? I imagine its a good thing to have even when theres no global supply-chain crisis, so why havent retailers done this already?</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse: </strong>Retailer organizations are doing the best they can, but we know that retailerslike companies in many other industriesare fairly siloed. Having an effective control tower relies on a few things. It relies on data, and, again, many retailers are operating disparate legacy systems and dont have one source of truth. It requires a lot of coordination between supply chain, marketing, and merchandisingand those entities havent always had the forum and, in some cases, the willingness to make difficult last-minute calls in a joint manner, day in and day out.</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee: </strong>Over the past 18 to 24 months, these supply-chain disruptions have awakened supply-chain officers in retail to the need for visibility. Theyve had to navigate some really challenging numbers, with <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/defining-on-time-in-full-in-the-consumer-sector">on-time in-full deliveries</a> to distribution centers in the neighborhood of 20 to 30 percent. Thats really disruptive. As they think about the future of their supply-chain capability, theyre now having to think hard about things like digital control towers, which, by the way, is not a new capability or technology; its been around for some time. Its just that over the past 18 to 24 months, in retail in particular, the need for these capabilities has really been heightened.</p>
<p>Traditionally, the challenge has been justifying the ROI for these visibility investments. Retailers know that visibility is good and will help them make better decisions, but theyve never really felt the need because theyve never had this level of disruption. So the time is right to pull in these types of capabilities.</p>
<h2>Shaping and forecasting consumer demand</h2>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello:</strong> Another lever you mentioned was shaping <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-consumer-demand-recovery-and-lasting-effects-of-covid-19">consumer demand</a>retailers seeking to influence what consumers buy and how they buy it. What are some ways retailers can do that?</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee: </strong>One thing that will never go away is the theater of stores. Stores will always have a role in the future of retail. Customers like to discover and explore and physically experience products; theres excitement in that. It may not make sense in all categories, but certainly for some, retailers should think about the theater of the store, how to showcase products and get customers excited, and what might get people out of their homes and into stores to the extent that its safe for them and their communities.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> During the height of the pandemic, one retail executive said, You know, Sarah, the thing thats shocking is that with everything going on in the world people are still coming to our stores and theyre still shopping. This was a nonessential retailer that had just reopened its stores. That stuck with methe notion that part of the reason we shop is because we need things, but another part of the reason we shop is because, when done well, retail is fun. So, to Johns point, retailers should think about <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/reimagining-stores-for-retails-next-normal">redefining the in-store experience</a> to make it something special, because the consumer is ready to get back into stores in addition to shopping online.</p>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello: </strong>Are consumers just going to have to pay higher prices? One of the shocking things you say in your article, Sarah, is that the <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/whats-going-on-with-shipping-rates">cost of shipping</a> an item could go up by $6 or more. Talk a little bit about pricing expectations, both from the consumers and the retailers perspective.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> Retailers want to provide the best value for their guests, so they try to figure out how much of the price increases they can absorb. But the margin structure means that when you are seeing the magnitude of price increases were seeing, retailers fundamentally cant absorb those increases and still remain profitable. So theyve needed to raise prices.</p>
<p>In October, <a href="/industries/chemicals/our-insights/getting-real-about-mitigating-price-inflation">inflation</a> was 5 percent, so I would say that, yes, consumers are already feeling it and seeing it. And as long as some of these exorbitant rates for getting product from here to there persist, well continue to see retailers raise prices even while they do their very best to try to think of creative ways to mitigate costs.</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee:</strong> Its hard to untrain consumers when theyre so used to certain levels of pricing. One of the elements of the American online market is the prevalence of free shipping. The US consumer has shown a resilient willingness, if you will, to not pay for any shipping costs. Thinking about the value equation onlinenot just the price of the goods but also the price of delivering the goodswill be important for the <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-survival-guide-to-omnichannel-and-the-path-to-value">economics and the P&L of an omnichannel retailer</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> I think some of the exorbitantly high rates that were seeing right now will calm down, but some of the underlying fundamentals of this market mean that getting products from place to place is getting more expensive. So building those costs into both your annual <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/launching-the-journey-to-autonomous-supply-chain-planning">operations planning</a> and your long-range planning is wise to do at this point.</p>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello:</strong> One of the things that seems to be very hard for retailers during this pandemic is anticipating consumer demand, because its been so volatile. Have you seen any retailers do a good job there? And if so, how have they done it?</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee:</strong> It has befuddled executives across all sectors, whether its grocery, apparel, home goods, sporting goods, and so on. What theyre grappling with is How much of the COVID-19 lift that we saw in the online channel is here to stay, and how much will shift back to stores? Will we continue to see positive comps [comparative-store sales]?</p>
<p>In some sectors, retailers were anticipating flat or even depressed sales going into this holiday season, and theyve been pleasantly surprisedcaught off guard, eventhat comps continue to be positive. Theyve been up anywhere between 8 and 15 percent compared with last year, and up 30 percent or more from 2019. This underscores the importance of great omnichannel fulfillment strategies to allow retailers to move product more seamlessly across their retail stores, their online channels, andto the extent that retailers choose to play in <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/moving-past-friend-or-foe-how-to-win-with-digital-marketplaces">marketplaces</a>in complementary nontraditional retail channels.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> The way that retailers forecast demand is being forced to change. Historically, if I were a planner, I would just take the prior years plan and make adjustments to it up, down, and sideways across categories, and that was my plan for the next year. Then 2020 happened, and retailers said, 2020 will be a one-time deviation versus 2019. But, as the pandemic persisted, they then said, 2021 will be another one-time deviation. Now, as we look toward 2022, it no longer makes sense to say that every year is just an absolute deviation from the year prior.</p>
<p>So some of the best retailers are going back to their analytics and saying, How can we get more sophisticated in looking at the demand signals in the market and getting <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/rapidly-forecasting-demand-and-adapting-commercial-plans-in-a-pandemic">more dynamic forecasts</a>? That way, its not a matter of looking at what happened last year and assuming that its going to continue, but really looking at whats happening in the market today and understanding what thats going to mean a few months hence.</p>
<h2>Supply-chain talent and capabilities</h2>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello: </strong>What does that mean for supply-chain capabilities? If youre hiring in your supply chain today, are you looking for different things than you were looking for in 2019?</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee:</strong> Capabilities, and <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/strategic-talent-management-for-the-post-pandemic-world">talent</a> more broadly, is generally one of the top three priorities of most chief supply-chain officers today. What theyve found, generally speaking, is that money is not enough to retain warehouse workers, so theyre exploring a number of creative benefits, whether thats paying for college, offering same-day pay, giving more time off or accelerated health benefits, and so on. I had an interesting conversation with a chief strategy officer at a retailer, who said that one of the things that retailers sometimes dont think about is <a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/men-think-childcare-is-affordable-women-dont">the need for childcare</a>.</p>
<p>As for back-office talent, the rise of automation in distribution centers and the use of technology and analytics are fundamentally shifting the skills of the contemporary supply-chain manager. Typically, in operations, it was about executing great processesgetting on the floor, working with people, and being in the moment in execution. Its very exhilarating, by the way.</p>
<p>But when we get into more automated environments, it requires a very different skill set to manage the end-to-end supply chain. It requires being able to interpret data and recognize patterns. And Id say one of the greatest shifts, particularly in omnichannel, is the cross-functional nature of how supply-chain managers need to work. To Sarahs earlier point, typically the supply chain was relatively siloed. Their task was to move goods from point A to point B in the most efficient way possible. Nowadays, supply chain requires close coordination with merchandising, marketing, inventory, and planning. Working with such a cross-functional team requires <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/craftsmanship-the-key-to-developing-talent-in-an-agile-organization">people who are more agile</a> than those youve historically seen in a supply-chain organization.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> One other aspect that is increasingly important is having true strategists who are sitting in supply-chain functions and thinking deeply about consumers. As John said, historically the thinking was that the commercial organization would set a value proposition and the supply-chain organization would execute on it. Now, our data would show that things like delivery speed and <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/returning-to-order-improving-returns-management-for-apparel-companies">return policies</a> have a big impact on how consumers think about that enterprise and its value proposition. So having strategists sitting in those roles who are thinking about the impact of their decisions not just on the bottom line but on the top line as well is increasingly important.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>One aspect that is increasingly important is having true strategists sit in supply-chain functions and think deeply about consumers.
</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Sarah Touse</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<h2>Advice to supply-chain officers: Recharge and reset</h2>
<p><strong>Monica Toriello:</strong> Lets close with this question: If all the supply-chain executives in the world were in one room and you could give them one message, what would it be?</p>
<p><strong>John Barbee: </strong>Having spoken with a number of chief supply-chain officers, I know the past 24 months have been a marathon. A lot of them are <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/overcoming-pandemic-fatigue-how-to-reenergize-organizations-for-the-long-run">tired and worn out</a>; theyre human beings. And theyve done a tremendous job of navigating an unprecedented amount of challenges.</p>
<p>As they take time to recharge themselves and their teams, I would urge them to think about resetting their own supply chain and challenge the way that retail supply chains have been set up for decades. Take risks. The COVID-19 pandemic proved to us that we can move quickly. We can test; sometimes well fail. Supply chain, by the way, hasnt always been thought of as one of those capabilities that you can quickly test and learn, because theres infrastructure that takes years to build, but weve turned that on its head. So I would encourage chief supply-chain officers to have the courage to take risks and use this as a moment to develop new sources of competitive advantage as they think about the future of retail.</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Touse:</strong> I would tell them, youve never had a better audience than you have now to really think through what you need for your supply chain to be successful, given all the disruption weve seen. Your CEO, your CFO, your boardtheyre all thinking about this. So, as temptingand perhaps necessaryas it is to just be in firefighting mode all day long, its imperative to take that step back and think about the future.</p>
<p>The other thing I would say is, all else equal, Im still able to go to the grocery store and get food. Im still able to get my kid a toy for Christmas. In an extraordinarily challenging environment, theres actually a lot to celebrate. The fundamental items we need to keep living the way that weve been living have continued to be available. In many cases, thats a testament to all of the great body of work thats happened over the past 24 months. Hopefully, theyll be able to kick back just a little bit over the holidays before jumping back into it in 2022.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div to master the omnichannel supply chain</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Retail supply chain strategies for the holidays and beyond","displayName":"Retail supply chain strategies for the holidays and beyond","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"930d459c-0b48-4b33-afdc-f68b648f8304","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Retail supply-chain strategies for the holidays and beyond"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Global supply-chain strategies for retailers during the holidays and beyond"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"How can retailers ensure strong sales this holiday season amid continuing supply-chain problems? Two McKinsey experts share their insights."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-11-12T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe disruptions in the global \u003c/strong\u003esupply chain are the result of a confluence of factors\u0026mdash;which means that retailers have to take action on multiple fronts if they want their store shelves stocked and online orders fulfilled on time. In this episode of the \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/em\u003e podcast, retail supply-chain experts John Barbee and Sarah Touse offer advice to retailers ahead of what\u0026rsquo;s shaping up to be another unusual holiday season. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003eSubscribe to the podcast\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[AUDIO 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello: \u003c/strong\u003eIf you haven\u0026rsquo;t done your holiday shopping yet, it might already be too late. That seems to be one of the takeaways from all the recent headlines about disruptions in the global supply chain. As has been reported, there are many reasons for these disruptions, so there isn\u0026rsquo;t one magic solution for retailers. Today, our two guests will share their insights on the range of supply-chain issues and what retailers can do in advance of what\u0026rsquo;s sure to be a challenging holiday shopping season.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJohn Barbee is a partner based in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Atlanta office. He works with many retailers and consumer-goods companies on their omnichannel, supply-chain, and fulfillment strategies. He is one of the authors of a recent article titled \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/retails-need-for-speed-unlocking-value-in-omnichannel-delivery\"\u003eRetail\u0026rsquo;s need for speed: Unlocking value in omnichannel delivery\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSarah Touse is an associate partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Boston office. Sarah, like John, has advised a wide range of retailers and consumer-goods players on supply-chain topics. Sarah has coauthored a number of retail articles, including one most recently on how retailers can build supply-chain resilience. Thanks for joining us, John and Sarah.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s been a lot of press about the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/themes/stretched-global-supply-chains-and-shortages\"\u003esupply-chain crisis\u003c/a\u003e, and it\u0026rsquo;s been attributed to a host of factors: logjams at ports; huge, unanticipated spikes in consumer demand; labor shortages; and so on. From your perspective, is there one thing that\u0026rsquo;s the biggest problem? Or are they all equally big problems?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee: \u003c/strong\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s a conundrum, Monica. There\u0026rsquo;s no single biggest problem. The good news is that some of the disruptions will pass, such as overseas vessel delays and container shortages. For these issues, the optimist would venture that they\u0026rsquo;d be resolved by the first half or early second half of next year. However, the pessimist might see this backlog last through 2023.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe other issues\u0026mdash;such as labor shortages\u0026mdash;have been a long time in the making. Hourly wage rates have escalated over 20 percent in the past 18 months, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/how-tech-will-revolutionize-retail\"\u003einvestments in technology\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/automation-in-retail-an-executive-overview-for-getting-ready\"\u003eautomation\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in distribution centers have been elevated and are now \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/how-retail-can-adapt-supply-chains-to-win-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eat the forefront of most chief supply-chain officers\u0026rsquo; agendas\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse: \u003c/strong\u003eThe numbers are just staggering. If you look at the resignation rate, it\u0026rsquo;s 13 percent higher than prepandemic levels. During the pandemic, 3.5 million people retired, which is two million more than usual. There are ten million job openings right now. There\u0026rsquo;s a whole host of factors underneath that, but for me one of the takeaways is just how fundamentally this pandemic has changed how Americans\u0026mdash;and people around the world\u0026mdash;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours\"\u003ethink about their careers and their jobs\u003c/a\u003e and how they want to spend time.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up retailpodcast]]\n\u003ch2\u003eRetailer strategies and no-regrets moves\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello:\u003c/strong\u003e What are some things that retailers have done that really made a difference in their supply chain or gave them competitive advantage?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse: \u003c/strong\u003eThere are a few things that smart retailers have done. One is around pricing and promotions timing. Whereas in some years Black Friday would be the day when the holiday season starts, this year we saw \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/us-holiday-shopping-2021-strong-demand-meets-big-challenges\"\u003eholiday pricing and promotions\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as early as October. Some of that \u0026ldquo;pull forward\u0026rdquo; to smooth out the demand curve has been important.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother thing that retailers have done is to thoughtfully raise prices. Some of the increases in logistics costs can\u0026rsquo;t be avoided even if you are a smart retailer, so understanding how much of that you can take to your bottom line and how much of it has to be passed along to the consumer\u0026mdash;and then thinking about how to do it in a way that\u0026rsquo;s minimally disruptive to the consumer\u0026mdash;has been really important.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd then, finally, retailers are thinking about supply-chain triage. Many retailers, earlier in the fall, recognized that these challenges were deep and they anticipated that they\u0026rsquo;d have trouble getting product when they wanted it. So, retailers that have been mindful about which products are most important to get onto shelves\u0026mdash;taking into account \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/can-your-supply-chain-deliver-what-your-consumer-wants\"\u003ewhat consumers want\u003c/a\u003e, as well as their own revenues and margins\u0026mdash;are seeing that advantage play out as we get closer to the holidays.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee:\u003c/strong\u003e There have been a few interesting retailer strategies that aren\u0026rsquo;t necessarily available to all retailers, but we\u0026rsquo;ve certainly read about some retailers\u0026mdash;such as Home Depot, Costco, Walmart, Ikea, Target, and others\u0026mdash;taking some of the shipping issues into their own hands, so it gives them a little bit more control. They\u0026rsquo;ve done this by leasing vessels to carry their containers from overseas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther retailers pre-bought capacity, particularly air freight. For those retailers that have more speed-sensitive product or seasonal product, this proved to be a good strategy in that they were able to bypass some of the shipping disruption. And in cases where they had excess capacity, they could even sell it to others.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e For last-mile delivery, historically, many retailers thought, \u0026ldquo;I\u0026rsquo;ve got FedEx, UPS, and the US Postal Service.\u0026rdquo; Those retailers are seeing the pain right now of very congested large integrator networks. A retailer that is now facing a little bit less pain is one that, a few years ago, decided to lean much more heavily on regional players\u0026mdash;the LaserShips of the world\u0026mdash;and that has enabled the retailer to have more avenues to get their products directly to consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello:\u003c/strong\u003e Are there any no-regrets moves that retailers should be making right now?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee: \u003c/strong\u003eIt comes down to the basics of \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/into-the-fast-lane-how-to-master-the-omnichannel-supply-chain\"\u003eomnichannel fulfillment operations\u003c/a\u003e. I think of this in two parts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePart one is that retailers should seek to maximize availability of product across all channels, offer convenient options for fulfilling demand, and make sure that the value of their product and fulfillment conveniences remains competitive in their market. In our latest consumer research, we find that \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/understanding-and-shaping-consumer-behavior-in-the-next-normal\"\u003econsumers continue to change their shopping behavior\u003c/a\u003e, with three-quarters making some change and 40 percent completely changing brands because of the lack of availability or perceived value in fulfillment. For chief supply-chain officers, this will mean working closely with their digital and store counterparts this holiday season to ensure that they have the blocking and tackling in place to deliver fast and reliable fulfillment to consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePart two is innovate. During this pandemic, retailers have really pushed the envelope on innovation. Things like curbside pickup, buy online and pick up in store, and even concierge services\u0026mdash;these things came to life faster than most retailers would have anticipated and fundamentally changed the way retailers think about deploying and testing new capabilities. So I think we will start to see a lot of experimentation with fulfillment models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe may see more partnerships. For instance, Best Buy partnered with Instacart, which has traditionally served the grocery market. The same is happening in the beauty category with Sephora. Kohl\u0026rsquo;s for some time has been taking Amazon returns. So there\u0026rsquo;s been a lot of \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-path-forward-for-the-us-retail-industry\"\u003einnovation in retail\u003c/a\u003e, and I think we\u0026rsquo;ll continue to see more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse: \u003c/strong\u003eI\u0026rsquo;ll highlight two things. The first is around visibility: the ROI of investing in greater data assets is always tricky for retailers. This pandemic has made it clear that data are important. Our recent research shows that a typical company will lose more than 40 percent of one year\u0026rsquo;s EBITDA [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization] over the next ten years because of disruption. Those numbers make the investment in data\u0026mdash;to enable retailers to have a more dynamic supply chain\u0026mdash;really seem well worth it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, retailers can do a lot to shape customer demand. As retailers think about how to push customers to buy online and pick up in store so that they can avoid some of that congested small-parcel market, and as they think about how to change shipping speeds and promises for different customer segments, it\u0026rsquo;s important to remember that customers react differently. There are things that retailers can do to shape some of those expectations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe need for visibility\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello: \u003c/strong\u003eBoth of you have mentioned visibility. Sarah, in your recent article, one of the things you say retailers must do in the near term is \u0026ldquo;stand up a digital control tower\u0026rdquo; so that they can have \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/building-a-digital-bridge-across-the-supply-chain-with-nerve-centers\"\u003ereal-time visibility into what\u0026rsquo;s happening in the supply chain\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;rather than having their data reside in siloed systems. You say a digital control tower \u0026ldquo;typically improves fill rate by 10 percent and reduces excess inventory by more than 30 percent.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCan you give us a sense of how hard it is for retailers to establish a digital control tower? I imagine it\u0026rsquo;s a good thing to have even when there\u0026rsquo;s no global supply-chain crisis, so why haven\u0026rsquo;t retailers done this already?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse: \u003c/strong\u003eRetailer organizations are doing the best they can, but we know that retailers\u0026mdash;like companies in many other industries\u0026mdash;are fairly siloed. Having an effective control tower relies on a few things. It relies on data, and, again, many retailers are operating disparate legacy systems and don\u0026rsquo;t have one source of truth. It requires a lot of coordination between supply chain, marketing, and merchandising\u0026mdash;and those entities haven\u0026rsquo;t always had the forum and, in some cases, the willingness to make difficult last-minute calls in a joint manner, day in and day out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee: \u003c/strong\u003eOver the past 18 to 24 months, these supply-chain disruptions have awakened supply-chain officers in retail to the need for visibility. They\u0026rsquo;ve had to navigate some really challenging numbers, with \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/defining-on-time-in-full-in-the-consumer-sector\"\u003eon-time in-full deliveries\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to distribution centers in the neighborhood of 20 to 30 percent. That\u0026rsquo;s really disruptive. As they think about the future of their supply-chain capability, they\u0026rsquo;re now having to think hard about things like digital control towers, which, by the way, is not a new capability or technology; it\u0026rsquo;s been around for some time. It\u0026rsquo;s just that over the past 18 to 24 months, in retail in particular, the need for these capabilities has really been heightened.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTraditionally, the challenge has been justifying the ROI for these visibility investments. Retailers know that visibility is good and will help them make better decisions, but they\u0026rsquo;ve never really felt the need because they\u0026rsquo;ve never had this level of disruption. So the time is right to pull in these types of capabilities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eShaping and forecasting consumer demand\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello:\u003c/strong\u003e Another lever you mentioned was shaping \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-consumer-demand-recovery-and-lasting-effects-of-covid-19\"\u003econsumer demand\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;retailers seeking to influence what consumers buy and how they buy it. What are some ways retailers can do that?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee: \u003c/strong\u003eOne thing that will never go away is the theater of stores. Stores will always have a role in the future of retail. Customers like to discover and explore and physically experience products; there\u0026rsquo;s excitement in that. It may not make sense in all categories, but certainly for some, retailers should think about the theater of the store, how to showcase products and get customers excited, and what might get people out of their homes and into stores to the extent that it\u0026rsquo;s safe for them and their communities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e During the height of the pandemic, one retail executive said, \u0026ldquo;You know, Sarah, the thing that\u0026rsquo;s shocking is that with everything going on in the world people are still coming to our stores and they\u0026rsquo;re still shopping.\u0026rdquo; This was a nonessential retailer that had just reopened its stores. That stuck with me\u0026mdash;the notion that part of the reason we shop is because we need things, but another part of the reason we shop is because, when done well, retail is fun. So, to John\u0026rsquo;s point, retailers should think about \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/reimagining-stores-for-retails-next-normal\"\u003eredefining the in-store experience\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to make it something special, because the consumer is ready to get back into stores in addition to shopping online.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello: \u003c/strong\u003eAre consumers just going to have to pay higher prices? One of the shocking things you say in your article, Sarah, is that the \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/whats-going-on-with-shipping-rates\"\u003ecost of shipping\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;an item could go up by $6 or more. Talk a little bit about pricing expectations, both from the consumer\u0026rsquo;s and the retailer\u0026rsquo;s perspective.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e Retailers want to provide the best value for their guests, so they try to figure out how much of the price increases they can absorb. But the margin structure means that when you are seeing the magnitude of price increases we\u0026rsquo;re seeing, retailers fundamentally can\u0026rsquo;t absorb those increases and still remain profitable. So they\u0026rsquo;ve needed to raise prices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn October, \u003ca href=\"/industries/chemicals/our-insights/getting-real-about-mitigating-price-inflation\"\u003einflation\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;was 5 percent, so I would say that, yes, consumers are already feeling it and seeing it. And as long as some of these exorbitant rates for getting product from here to there persist, we\u0026rsquo;ll continue to see retailers raise prices even while they do their very best to try to think of creative ways to mitigate costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee:\u003c/strong\u003e It\u0026rsquo;s hard to untrain consumers when they\u0026rsquo;re so used to certain levels of pricing. One of the elements of the American online market is the prevalence of free shipping. The US consumer has shown a resilient willingness, if you will, to not pay for any shipping costs. Thinking about the value equation online\u0026mdash;not just the price of the goods but also the price of delivering the goods\u0026mdash;will be important for the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-survival-guide-to-omnichannel-and-the-path-to-value\"\u003eeconomics and the P\u0026amp;L of an omnichannel retailer\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e I think some of the exorbitantly high rates that we\u0026rsquo;re seeing right now will calm down, but some of the underlying fundamentals of this market mean that getting products from place to place is getting more expensive. So building those costs into both your annual \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/launching-the-journey-to-autonomous-supply-chain-planning\"\u003eoperations planning\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and your long-range planning is wise to do at this point.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello:\u003c/strong\u003e One of the things that seems to be very hard for retailers during this pandemic is anticipating consumer demand, because it\u0026rsquo;s been so volatile. Have you seen any retailers do a good job there? And if so, how have they done it?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee:\u003c/strong\u003e It has befuddled executives across all sectors, whether it\u0026rsquo;s grocery, apparel, home goods, sporting goods, and so on. What they\u0026rsquo;re grappling with is \u0026ldquo;How much of the COVID-19 lift that we saw in the online channel is here to stay, and how much will shift back to stores? Will we continue to see positive comps [comparative-store sales]?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn some sectors, retailers were anticipating flat or even depressed sales going into this holiday season, and they\u0026rsquo;ve been pleasantly surprised\u0026mdash;caught off guard, even\u0026mdash;that comps continue to be positive. They\u0026rsquo;ve been up anywhere between 8 and 15 percent compared with last year, and up 30 percent or more from 2019. This underscores the importance of great omnichannel fulfillment strategies to allow retailers to move product more seamlessly across their retail stores, their online channels, and\u0026mdash;to the extent that retailers choose to play in \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/moving-past-friend-or-foe-how-to-win-with-digital-marketplaces\"\u003emarketplaces\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;in complementary nontraditional retail channels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e The way that retailers forecast demand is being forced to change. Historically, if I were a planner, I would just take the prior year\u0026rsquo;s plan and make adjustments to it up, down, and sideways across categories, and that was my plan for the next year. Then 2020 happened, and retailers said, \u0026ldquo;2020 will be a one-time deviation versus 2019.\u0026rdquo; But, as the pandemic persisted, they then said, \u0026ldquo;2021 will be another one-time deviation.\u0026rdquo; Now, as we look toward 2022, it no longer makes sense to say that every year is just an absolute deviation from the year prior.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo some of the best retailers are going back to their analytics and saying, \u0026ldquo;How can we get more sophisticated in looking at the demand signals in the market and getting \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/rapidly-forecasting-demand-and-adapting-commercial-plans-in-a-pandemic\"\u003emore dynamic forecasts\u003c/a\u003e?\u0026rdquo; That way, it\u0026rsquo;s not a matter of looking at what happened last year and assuming that it\u0026rsquo;s going to continue, but really looking at what\u0026rsquo;s happening in the market today and understanding what that\u0026rsquo;s going to mean a few months hence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSupply-chain talent and capabilities\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello: \u003c/strong\u003eWhat does that mean for supply-chain capabilities? If you\u0026rsquo;re hiring in your supply chain today, are you looking for different things than you were looking for in 2019?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee:\u003c/strong\u003e Capabilities, and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/strategic-talent-management-for-the-post-pandemic-world\"\u003etalent\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;more broadly, is generally one of the top three priorities of most chief supply-chain officers today. What they\u0026rsquo;ve found, generally speaking, is that money is not enough to retain warehouse workers, so they\u0026rsquo;re exploring a number of creative benefits, whether that\u0026rsquo;s paying for college, offering same-day pay, giving more time off or accelerated health benefits, and so on. I had an interesting conversation with a chief strategy officer at a retailer, who said that one of the things that retailers sometimes don\u0026rsquo;t think about is \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/men-think-childcare-is-affordable-women-dont\"\u003ethe need for childcare\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs for back-office talent, the rise of automation in distribution centers and the use of technology and analytics are fundamentally shifting the skills of the contemporary supply-chain manager. Typically, in operations, it was about executing great processes\u0026mdash;getting on the floor, working with people, and being \u0026ldquo;in the moment\u0026rdquo; in execution. It\u0026rsquo;s very exhilarating, by the way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut when we get into more automated environments, it requires a very different skill set to manage the end-to-end supply chain. It requires being able to interpret data and recognize patterns. And I\u0026rsquo;d say one of the greatest shifts, particularly in omnichannel, is the cross-functional nature of how supply-chain managers need to work. To Sarah\u0026rsquo;s earlier point, typically the supply chain was relatively siloed. Their task was to move goods from point A to point B in the most efficient way possible. Nowadays, supply chain requires close coordination with merchandising, marketing, inventory, and planning. Working with such a cross-functional team requires \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-organization-blog/craftsmanship-the-key-to-developing-talent-in-an-agile-organization\"\u003epeople who are more agile\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;than those you\u0026rsquo;ve historically seen in a supply-chain organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e One other aspect that is increasingly important is having true strategists who are sitting in supply-chain functions and thinking deeply about consumers. As John said, historically the thinking was that the commercial organization would set a value proposition and the supply-chain organization would execute on it. Now, our data would show that things like delivery speed and \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/returning-to-order-improving-returns-management-for-apparel-companies\"\u003ereturn policies\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;have a big impact on how consumers think about that enterprise and its value proposition. So having strategists sitting in those roles who are thinking about the impact of their decisions not just on the bottom line but on the top line as well is increasingly important.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eAdvice to supply-chain officers: Recharge and reset\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMonica Toriello:\u003c/strong\u003e Let\u0026rsquo;s close with this question: If all the supply-chain executives in the world were in one room and you could give them one message, what would it be?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Barbee: \u003c/strong\u003eHaving spoken with a number of chief supply-chain officers, I know the past 24 months have been a marathon. A lot of them are \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/overcoming-pandemic-fatigue-how-to-reenergize-organizations-for-the-long-run\"\u003etired and worn out\u003c/a\u003e; they\u0026rsquo;re human beings. And they\u0026rsquo;ve done a tremendous job of navigating an unprecedented amount of challenges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs they take time to recharge themselves and their teams, I would urge them to think about resetting their own supply chain and challenge the way that retail supply chains have been set up for decades. Take risks. The COVID-19 pandemic proved to us that we can move quickly. We can test; sometimes we\u0026rsquo;ll fail. Supply chain, by the way, hasn\u0026rsquo;t always been thought of as one of those capabilities that you can quickly test and learn, because there\u0026rsquo;s infrastructure that takes years to build, but we\u0026rsquo;ve turned that on its head. So I would encourage chief supply-chain officers to have the courage to take risks and use this as a moment to develop new sources of competitive advantage as they think about the future of retail.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSarah Touse:\u003c/strong\u003e I would tell them, you\u0026rsquo;ve never had a better audience than you have now to really think through what you need for your supply chain to be successful, given all the disruption we\u0026rsquo;ve seen. Your CEO, your CFO, your board\u0026mdash;they\u0026rsquo;re all thinking about this. So, as tempting\u0026mdash;and perhaps necessary\u0026mdash;as it is to just be in firefighting mode all day long, it\u0026rsquo;s imperative to take that step back and think about the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe other thing I would say is, all else equal, I\u0026rsquo;m still able to go to the grocery store and get food. I\u0026rsquo;m still able to get my kid a toy for Christmas. In an extraordinarily challenging environment, there\u0026rsquo;s actually a lot to celebrate. The fundamental items we need to keep living the way that we\u0026rsquo;ve been living have continued to be available. In many cases, that\u0026rsquo;s a testament to all of the great body of work that\u0026rsquo;s happened over the past 24 months. Hopefully, they\u0026rsquo;ll be able to kick back just a little bit over the holidays before jumping back into it in 2022.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
